### Steps to reproduce

If you attempt to copy a directory recursively into a subdirectory of the first directory you eventually encounter a path too long error.

**Note:** Yes, I know that you shouldn't try doing this. I recently encountered an automated process that performed a similar function by accident, and thus how I discovered that PowerShell also behaves this same way.

### Expected behavior

```console
PS> New-Item a/a -Type Directory
PS> Copy-Item a a/a -Recurse
<Probably a terminating error that you can't recursively copy a directory into itself>
```


### Actual behavior

```console
~> mkdir a/a

UnixMode   User             Group                 LastWriteTime           Size Name
--------   ----             -----                 -------------           ---- ----
drwxr-xr-x coryknox         staff              2022-06-15 11:33             64 a

~> copy-item a a/a -Recurse
Copy-Item: The path '' is too long, or a component of the specified path is too long.
Copy-Item: The path '' is too long, or a component of the specified path is too long.
```

comments.body: It is interesting to note that the error about the path being too long does not occur on Windows (or at least, it doesn't in 11.5 minutes of running to generate 3600+ directories 😂 ).

comments.author: iRon7
comments.body:
Rather than disallowing it, you might also (in case of a subdirectory) consider to *get all source items first* and than paste it to the destination.
What I mean is (sometimes it is easier to explain it in PowerShell than in English 😊):

Instead of:
<Strike>
```PowerShell
Get-ChildItem A -Recurse |Copy-Item A/A
```
</Strike>

Implement this (in case it concerns a sub-folder):
```PowerShell
(Get-ChildItem A -Recurse) |Copy-Item A/A # note the parenthesis
```

title: Recursively copying a directory into a subdirectory should not be allowed
